responses: Hey there, survivor. How are you holding up?
Good to hear from you. Stay sharp out there.

categories.name: medicine
responses: For bleeding, apply firm direct pressure and elevate the limb; use a tourniquet only as last resort.
Clean wounds with boiled/purified water and antiseptic. Keep wounds covered and watch for infection.
If bones look deformed, immobilize with a splint and seek help; don't attempt to reset unless trained.

categories.name: combat
responses: Aim for the head: destroying the brain neutralizes zombies. Conserve ammo.
Prefer silent melee weapons (crowbar, machete) to avoid attracting others.
Use choke points and high ground for ambushes; always plan an escape route.

categories.name: hiding
responses: Choose hiding spots with multiple exits and natural concealment; avoid high-traffic areas.
Move slowly, stay low, and minimize noise — silence is your friend.
Mask smells with mud or strong, consistent local odors; avoid perfumes.

categories.name: food
responses: Prioritize water purification: boil 1+ minute, or filter with charcoal/sand.
Canned goods, rice, beans, and peanut butter last. Ration portions and rotate supplies.
Forage known safe plants; avoid mushrooms unless 100% certain.

categories.name: adaptability
responses: Keep routines to preserve mental health: tasks, training, and small goals every day.
Assign roles and responsibilities in groups to reduce chaos and improve efficiency.
Prepare contingency plans for every mission — always have a fallback.

categories.name: tools
responses: Essential kit: water filter, multitool, knife, firestarter, flashlight, spare batteries, duct tape, basic medkit.
Pack light but prioritize water, food, first-aid, and shelter materials. Distribute weight evenly.
Maintain tools: oil metal, keep blades dry, sharpen regularly.

categories.name: navigation
responses: Use the sun (east morning, west evening) and stars at night; moss often grows on north side of trees in northern hemisphere.
Draw local maps marking safehouses, water, and danger zones. Carry paper copies.
Avoid predictable routes; plan multiple exits and avoid chokepoints.

categories.name: communication
responses: Use short radio calls with code names; change channels regularly and keep messages brief.
Establish silent hand signals for movement, danger, and regrouping to preserve stealth.
Use colored cloth or mirror flashes for long-distance signals; agree on meanings beforehand.

categories.name: emergency
responses: Signal SOS with light (Morse: 3 short, 3 long, 3 short) or three smoke puffs for visibility.
Set up triage: stop bleeding first, then airway/breathing, then shock/hypothermia.
If evacuating, take essentials: water, medkit, critical documents, and a compact weapon.

medical.title: Treating Wounds
medical.tip: Clean wounds with boiled/purified water or antiseptic. Pat dry, apply antibiotic ointment if available, and cover with a sterile dressing. Change dressings and monitor for infection.

medical.title: Stopping Severe Bleeding
medical.tip: Apply firm direct pressure to the wound using a clean cloth. Elevate the limb above the heart. If bleeding doesn't stop, use a tourniquet above the wound as a last resort and note time applied.

medical.title: Identifying Infection
medical.tip: Look for redness, swelling, increasing pain, pus, foul odor, or fever. Clean and drain if necessary; use antibiotics if available and seek medical attention.

medical.title: Splinting Broken Bones
medical.tip: Immobilize the limb using rigid supports (sticks, boards) and soft padding. Secure with cloth or bandages above and below the suspected fracture. Do not attempt to realign bones.

medical.title: Makeshift Pain Relief
medical.tip: If pharmaceuticals are unavailable, white willow bark tea (salicin), ginger, or turmeric can reduce pain/inflammation. Use cautiously and be aware of allergies.

medical.title: Field Suturing Basics
medical.tip: Sterilize a needle and thread (fishing line works). Clean wound thoroughly. Use simple interrupted stitches for deep cuts only if bleeding is controlled and infection risk is understood.

medical.title: Burn Care
medical.tip: Cool burn under clean running water for 10-20 minutes. Cover with sterile non-stick dressing. Do not apply ice or greasy substances. Seek medical help for severe burns.

medical.title: Treating Shock
medical.tip: Lay person flat, elevate feet unless spinal injury suspected, keep warm and calm. Control bleeding and seek urgent care.

medical.title: Eye Irrigation
medical.tip: Rinse eye with clean water or saline for at least 10-15 minutes. If object persists or vision is impaired, seek medical attention.

medical.title: Recognizing Dehydration
medical.tip: Signs: dry mouth, dark urine, dizziness. Rehydrate slowly with small sips of filtered or treated water. Add electrolytes if available.

medical.title: Basic Hygiene to Prevent Illness
medical.tip: Wash hands with soap and water frequently. Boil water used for washing dishes. Keep living area clean and dispose of waste away from living spaces.

medical.title: Treating Bites (Non-critical)
medical.tip: Clean the area thoroughly, control bleeding, apply antiseptic, and bandage. Monitor closely for infection. Seek medical help for deep or facial bites.

medical.title: Managing Fever
medical.tip: Lower fever with fluids, cool cloths, and rest. Use fever reducers if available. Monitor for signs of worsening infection.

medical.title: Allergic Reaction Response
medical.tip: If breathing is compromised or swelling of face/throat occurs, use epinephrine if available and seek immediate help. Lay person down with legs elevated.

medical.title: Basic CPR Reminder
medical.tip: If trained: compressions at 100-120/min, 2 inches deep for adults. Alternate 30 compressions with 2 rescue breaths, or use hands-only CPR if untrained.

medical.title: Sterilizing Instruments
medical.tip: Boil metal tools for at least 5 minutes or immerse in diluted bleach solution (1:10) briefly and rinse with clean water before use.

medical.title: Treating Hypothermia
medical.tip: Move to warm shelter, replace wet clothing, use blankets or body heat to warm. Offer warm (not hot) liquids if conscious.

medical.title: Heat Exhaustion and Heatstroke
medical.tip: Cool down quickly: shade, remove excess clothing, sponge with cool water, hydrate. Heatstroke (confusion, unconsciousness) needs immediate medical care.

medical.title: Storing Medications Safely
medical.tip: Keep meds in sealed containers, away from moisture and heat. Label with use-by dates and keep a basic inventory list.

medical.title: Preventing Infection in Group Settings
medical.tip: Isolate symptomatic individuals, maintain good hygiene, disinfect shared surfaces, and limit shared utensils.

medical.title: Recognizing Serious Internal Injury
medical.tip: Look for abdominal pain, distension, fainting, pale skin — treat for shock and get to medical care urgently if possible.

combat.title: Choosing Weapons
combat.tip: Pick durable, easy-to-maintain, and quiet weapons. Crowbars and machetes are versatile; avoid noisy firearms unless necessary.

combat.title: Silent Takedowns
combat.tip: Approach from behind, control limbs, and target the skull or neck using blades or blunt force while minimizing noise.

combat.title: Aim for the Brain
combat.tip: Zombies are neutralized by destroying the brain. Aim carefully and conserve ammunition—one precise shot is better than many misses.

combat.title: Defensive Stance
combat.tip: Keep knees slightly bent, weight balanced, hands ready. Protect your core and maintain situational awareness.

combat.title: Weapon Maintenance
combat.tip: Regularly clean, oil, and inspect weapons. Sharpen blades, tighten fittings, and check moving parts to prevent failures.

combat.title: Ambush and Trap Placement
combat.tip: Use terrain and concealment. Place traps on likely paths, create false routes, and ensure quick escape routes for your team.

combat.title: Using Firearms Wisely
combat.tip: Firearms are loud and attract attention. Use only when necessary, aim carefully, and maintain ammo discipline.

combat.title: Improvised Weapons
combat.tip: Convert pipes, chair legs, or tools into blunt weapons. Ensure they are sturdy and balanced to avoid breaking mid-use.

combat.title: Multi-attacker Awareness
combat.tip: Back toward an exit or narrow choke point, keep attackers in front, use sweeping strikes to keep distance.

combat.title: Keeping Quiet in Combat
combat.tip: Avoid metal-on-metal contact and shouting. Use cloth-wrapped weapons to muffle impact and communicate via hand signals.

combat.title: Disarming Traps and Hazards
combat.tip: Approach carefully, use poles or probes first, look for tripwire or pressure triggers, and remove or bypass rather than trigger.

combat.title: Group Combat Coordination
combat.tip: Assign roles (point, rear guard, medic), use signals, and synchronize attacks to overwhelm threats while protecting non-combatants.

combat.title: Sparse Ammo Tactics
combat.tip: Use melee for routine encounters; reserve bullets for large groups or armored threats. Aim for high-value targets.

combat.title: Using Environment as Weapon
combat.tip: Lead threats into hazards (fires, cliffs) or create barriers to slow them down. Use falling objects or collapsing structures when safe.

combat.title: Hand-to-Hand Defense
combat.tip: Target vulnerable areas: eyes, throat, groin. Stay balanced, strike quickly, and disengage to avoid grappling with infected.

combat.title: Avoiding Ambushes
combat.tip: Move with scouts, use high vantage points to observe, and avoid traveling predictable routes that could be trapped.

combat.title: Night Operations
combat.tip: Use minimal light, know your terrain beforehand, and use thermal or night optics if available. Move silently.

combat.title: Recovering Weapons Safely
combat.tip: Ensure area is secure before retrieving dropped weapons. Check for bio-contamination and clean before reuse.

combat.title: Dealing with Armored Threats
combat.tip: Focus on exposed areas (neck, joints). Use heavy blunt force or fire to penetrate armor if ammunition and safety permit.

combat.title: Retreat and Reposition
combat.tip: If overwhelmed, withdraw to predetermined fallback points, maintain suppressive actions while retreating, and regroup quickly.

hiding.title: Best Hiding Spots
hiding.tip: Choose locations with few approaches and at least two exits. Prefer cool, dark, and dry spaces with concealment.

hiding.title: Avoiding Detection
hiding.tip: Move slowly, minimize gear noise, avoid lights, and cover reflective surfaces. Plan route and rehearse movement.

hiding.title: Masking Scent
hiding.tip: Mask human scent with strong consistent local odors (mud, ash). Avoid fragrances and new smells that could attract attention.

hiding.title: Nighttime Movement
hiding.tip: Use moonlight and natural shadows. Move only when you know the route. Watch for humans — they may be more active at night.

hiding.title: Creating Camouflage
hiding.tip: Break up silhouette with natural materials, use muted colors, and avoid reflective surfaces. Match local environment textures.

hiding.title: Silent Entry Techniques
hiding.tip: Use gloves, avoid metal tools that squeak, and pre-check doors/windows for hazards. Slow is silent.

hiding.title: Fortifying a Cache
hiding.tip: Conceal supplies in false bottoms or high places. Mark with subtle code only your group understands.

hiding.title: Shelter Selection
hiding.tip: Prefer structures that are defensible, have water access, and are not obvious to others (avoid big shopping centers).

hiding.title: Maintaining Low Profile
hiding.tip: Minimize visible signs of habitation: no fires in plain sight, limit comings and goings, and keep noise to a minimum.

hiding.title: Emergency Concealment
hiding.tip: If surprised, find nearest dark recess, stay still, control breathing, and cover mouth to muffle sound.

hiding.title: Noise Discipline
hiding.tip: Establish rules for noise: no loud tools, no radios at full volume, and communicate with hand signals.

hiding.title: Using Dummy Decoys
hiding.tip: Create fake tracks or noise sources away from your base to divert attention. Use sparingly to avoid pattern recognition.

food.title: Safe Foraging
food.tip: Learn and rely on a short trusted list of edible plants in your region. When unsure, boil and test small amounts over days for reactions.

food.title: Water Purification
food.tip: Boil water at a rolling boil 1-3 minutes depending on altitude. Use layered charcoal/sand filters.

food.title: Urban Scavenging
food.tip: Check grocery break rooms, restaurant storage, basements, and delivery bays. Move quickly, note exits, and avoid confrontations.

food.title: Fishing Without Gear
food.tip: Use baited bottle traps, weirs, or sharpened sticks. Target shallow calm areas and watch for currents.

food.title: Preserving Meat
food.tip: Salt or smoke meat to preserve. Dry low and slow. Keep in clean containers away from insects.

food.title: Rationing Strategy
food.tip: Calculate daily calorie needs and portion supplies to stretch. Prioritize high-calorie, nutrient-dense foods.

food.title: Safe Dairy Use
food.tip: Use pasteurized dairy when possible. Cheese and clarified butter preserve better than milk.

food.title: Cooking Without Gas
food.tip: Use simple twig/wood stoves, solar ovens, or improvised rocket stoves. Cook thoroughly to avoid pathogens.

food.title: Gathering Edible Insects
food.tip: Crickets, mealworms, and certain larvae are high-protein; roast or boil thoroughly and avoid brightly colored species.

food.title: Storing Food Safely
food.tip: Store in airtight containers, keep away from moisture, use elevated caches to deter pests, and label with dates.

food.title: Making Emergency Meals
food.tip: Combine rice or pasta with protein (canned/jerky) and freeze-dried veggies. Fortify with oils for calories.

food.title: Finding Water Sources
food.tip: Look for green vegetation, animal tracks to water, and low-lying areas. Collect rainwater and dew where possible.

food.title: Using Solar Still
food.tip: Dig a hole, put a container in center, cover with plastic, weight center with stone to collect evaporated water into container.

food.title: Bartering Food
food.tip: Trade based on supply demand: medical supplies and fuel are high value, trade for long-lasting food items.

adaptability.title: Mental Resilience
adaptability.tip: Create routines, set small daily goals, exercise, and foster social bonds to maintain morale and mental health.

adaptability.title: Group Dynamics
adaptability.tip: Assign clear roles, set rules, rotate duties, and resolve conflicts quickly. Trust but verify newcomers.

adaptability.title: Solo vs Group Choice
adaptability.tip: Solo is stealthier and flexible; groups provide security and shared skills. Choose based on mission and resources.

adaptability.title: Improvisation Skills
adaptability.tip: Repurpose items: belts as straps, curtains as ropes, cans as cook pots. Think multi-use when scavenging.

adaptability.title: Maintaining Physical Fitness
adaptability.tip: Daily calisthenics, load-bearing walks, and functional training keep you ready for evacuations and combat.

adaptability.title: Learning New Skills Quickly
adaptability.tip: Use short focused practice sessions and peer teaching; prioritize life-saving skills (first aid, navigation, fire-starting).

adaptability.title: Energy Conservation
adaptability.tip: Limit heavy activity to cooler parts of day, rest frequently, and prioritize tasks to conserve calories and energy.

adaptability.title: Adapting to Climate
adaptability.tip: In cold: layer clothing, insulate shelter, avoid sweating. In heat: stay hydrated, shade, and rest mid-day.

adaptability.title: Resource Rotation
adaptability.tip: Use FIFO (first in, first out) for perishable items and regularly inventory to prevent waste.

adaptability.title: Teaching Others
adaptability.tip: Teach essential tasks in short drills with feedback. Create cheat-sheets and visual aids for quick learning.

adaptability.title: Adapting Communication
adaptability.tip: Switch to non-verbal and coded messages when radio or phones are too risky. Rotate codes periodically.

adaptability.title: Psychological First Aid
adaptability.tip: Listen, validate feelings, provide practical help, and connect to group supports. Encourage routine and small achievements.

adaptability.title: Managing Scarcity
adaptability.tip: Prioritize critical needs, identify renewable resources, and establish fair sharing rules to maintain social cohesion.

adaptability.title: Redundancy Planning
adaptability.tip: Create backups for routes, caches, and roles. Assume a primary option will fail and prepare alternatives.

adaptability.title: Rapid Decision Making
adaptability.tip: Use simple heuristics: safety > speed > comfort. Delegate smaller decisions to reduce bottlenecking.

tools_and_gear.title: Must-Have Tools
tools_and_gear.tip: Multitool, fixed-blade knife, water filter, firestarter, flashlight, spare batteries, duct tape, paracord, and basic medkit.

tools_and_gear.title: Backpack Packing Order
tools_and_gear.tip: Keep frequently used items accessible (water, radio, medkit). Place heavy items close to back and balance weight.

tools_and_gear.title: Fire Starting Options
tools_and_gear.tip: Carry multiple methods: ferro rod, waterproof matches, lighter, and tinder. Practice using them in windy/wet conditions.

tools_and_gear.title: Water Filtration Tools
tools_and_gear.tip: Use ceramic/carbon filters and treat with tablets/boil afterwards to remove pathogens and pollutants.

tools_and_gear.title: Light Without Power
tools_and_gear.tip: Use headlamps, LED lanterns, candles in jars, or DIY bottle-lanterns. Keep light low to avoid detection.

tools_and_gear.title: Repair Kits
tools_and_gear.tip: Carry needle, thread, spare buckles, zip ties, tape, spare screws, and basic tools to repair gear quickly.

tools_and_gear.title: Weapon Care Kit
tools_and_gear.tip: Include oil, cleaning rods, patches, small file, and spare parts. Clean after each use and store dry.

tools_and_gear.title: Clothing Choices
tools_and_gear.tip: Layer clothing for temperature control. Use neutral colors for concealment. Waterproof outer layers are essential.

tools_and_gear.title: Portable Shelter Options
tools_and_gear.tip: Tarps and bivvy sacks are lightweight and versatile. Rig tarps low to block wind and high for ventilation depending on climate.

tools_and_gear.title: Navigation Gear
tools_and_gear.tip: Carry a map and compass; learn to use them without electronics. Mark caches and safe routes on paper maps.

tools_and_gear.title: Storage and Caching
tools_and_gear.tip: Use waterproof containers, bury or elevate caches, and mark subtly. Rotate caches and keep locations known only to trusted members.

tools_and_gear.title: Signaling Tools
tools_and_gear.tip: Keep a small set of signaling devices—whistle, signal mirror, flares—for emergencies; train everyone on codes.

tools_and_gear.title: Energy Sources
tools_and_gear.tip: Prioritize solar chargers and efficient batteries. Keep devices in airplane mode to save power when not needed.

tools_and_gear.title: Hygiene Kit
tools_and_gear.tip: Include soap, toothbrush, menstrual supplies, small towel, hand sanitizer, and basic disinfectants to reduce disease spread.

tools_and_gear.title: Tool Multipurpose Use
tools_and_gear.tip: Choose gear for multiple functions (knife that carves and digs, tarp that shelters and signals) to save weight and increase utility.

navigation.title: Navigating Without GPS
navigation.tip: Use sun position, stars, and landmarks. Moss often grows on north side of trees in northern hemisphere; confirm with multiple observations.

navigation.title: Drawing Local Maps
navigation.tip: Record landmarks, danger zones, water sources, and caches. Keep maps updated and distribute copies to trusted allies.

navigation.title: Using a Compass
navigation.tip: Hold compass level, rotate to orient, and follow bearings. Take multiple bearings to triangulate position.

navigation.title: Reading the Sky
navigation.tip: Red sky at night often indicates stable weather next day; quick cloud build-up can mean storms. Use sky observations plus local cues.

navigation.title: Avoiding Chokepoints
navigation.tip: Avoid confined routes like tunnels and narrow bridges unless scouted; these limit escape options and make ambushes easy.

navigation.title: Creating Trail Markers
navigation.tip: Use subtle markers (stacked stones, small scratches) that your group recognizes. Avoid obvious marks visible to aerial observers.

navigation.title: Estimating Distance
navigation.tip: Use pace counting (steps per 100m) and map scale to estimate distance. Time travel based on terrain and load.

navigation.title: Night Navigation
navigation.tip: Use low light, follow natural contours, and avoid unknown areas. Use moon and stars if visible. Move slowly and listen.

navigation.title: Using Landmarks Safely
navigation.tip: Choose landmarks that are not likely to be destroyed or changed; note secondary landmarks in case primary is altered.

navigation.title: Finding Roads and Paths
navigation.tip: Follow minor roads and paths cautiously—these can lead to settlements or danger. Observe from cover before entering.

communication.title: Using Silent Signals
communication.tip: Agree on simple hand signals for move, stop, danger, regroup, and help. Practice until instinctive.

communication.title: Radio Protocol
communication.tip: Use short transmissions, code names, and rotate channels. Assume radios are monitored—avoid revealing locations.

communication.title: Whistle Codes
communication.tip: Two short = regroup, one long = danger, three short = help. Keep whistles on your person and teach to all members.

communication.title: Chalk and Marking Codes
communication.tip: Use symbols for 'safe', 'danger', and directional arrows. Keep codes simple and known only to group to avoid giving info to others.

communication.title: Using Mirrors and Light
communication.tip: Reflect sunlight in short bursts for long-distance signaling. Use with care, as reflections can reveal position.

emergency_signals.title: SOS with Light
emergency_signals.tip: Use three short, three long, three short flashes for SOS. Repeat periodically and from covered positions if possible.

emergency_signals.title: Smoke Signals
emergency_signals.tip: Create three distinct puffs or columns for attention; use wet leaves for thick smoke and darker colors for visibility.

emergency_signals.title: Ground Symbols
emergency_signals.tip: Draw large symbols or arrows in open ground for overhead observers; keep meanings standardized among allies.

emergency_signals.title: Hanging Cloth or Flag
emergency_signals.tip: Hang colored cloth in visible places as pre-agreed signals (e.g., red = danger, green = safe). Keep colors consistent across group.

emergency_signals.title: Whistle and Horn Use
emergency_signals.tip: Use short, loud sounds to attract help or distract threats, but use sparingly to avoid drawing unwanted attention.

psychological_survival.title: Managing Fear
psychological_survival.tip: Use breathing exercises, focus on present tasks, and rely on routines. Small, achievable tasks reduce anxiety.

psychological_survival.title: Avoiding Cabin Fever
psychological_survival.tip: Rotate activities, schedule social time, exercise, and create learning tasks to keep minds engaged.

psychological_survival.title: Coping with Loss
psychological_survival.tip: Allow time for mourning, provide support, and maintain practical survival needs. Rituals can help closure.

psychological_survival.title: Maintaining Morale
psychological_survival.tip: Celebrate small wins, keep a shared purpose, and rotate leadership to prevent burnout.

psychological_survival.title: Dealing with Betrayal
psychological_survival.tip: Verify information before drastic action, keep contingency plans, and maintain security protocols for access.

children_and_family.title: Explaining Danger to Kids
children_and_family.tip: Use simple rules (stay quiet, stay close), turn training into games, and avoid frightening details while emphasizing safety.

children_and_family.title: Keeping Children Safe
children_and_family.tip: Always pair children with an adult, give them visible identifiers, and teach them whistle or signal use.

children_and_family.title: Family Travel Protocols
children_and_family.tip: Assign roles: lead, rear guard, child-tender. Move during low risk windows and keep children in center of formation.

children_and_family.title: Child-Friendly Food
children_and_family.tip: Offer soft, calorie-dense foods like mashed beans, rice, and dried fruit. Ensure hydration and avoid choking hazards.

children_and_family.title: Teaching Teens Survival Skills
children_and_family.tip: Teach practical tasks: navigation, first aid, basic tool use, and simple defense. Teens can be valuable team members.
